Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of physical presence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Bloxom spent only 421 days in Canada during the relevant four-year period
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – 421 days out of required 1095 days
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge considered irrelevant factors; judicial review sought on procedural grounds
Evidence_Used: Record of Bloxom's physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or proof of residency meeting statutory threshold
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; original decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Bloxom did not meet the mandatory 1095-day physical presence requirement; statutory compliance is objective

Application_Facts: Chehade was absent for 454 days due to business in the United Arab Emirates; maintained family ties and some formal connections but did not centralize mode of living in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court Trial Division with submission of new evidence
Evidence_Used: Duration of absence, nature of business activities abroad, maintenance of family ties and formal connections in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate centralization of mode of living in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and allowance of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of physical residence in Canada within four years preceding application under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Chehade did not meet the residency requirement as he failed to centralize his mode of living in Canada despite maintaining some ties

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Koo was physically present in Canada for only 232 days within the four-year period preceding his application; maintained business interests in Hong Kong; made frequent visits to Canada but did not establish it as his primary residence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a decision of a Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence, travel history, ties to Hong Kong, nature and frequency of visits to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of established residence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years (1095 days) of accumulated residence in Canada within four years prior to application under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Koo did not meet the statutory residency requirement; Canada was not his primary residence; temporary visits insufficient to satisfy residency obligation

Application_Facts: Applicants were denied citizenship due to insufficient physical presence; applicants were abroad during assessment period
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to review residency questionnaires; lack of fair hearing
Evidence_Used: Residency questionnaires (not reviewed)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not consider submitted questionnaires
Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a different citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) residency requirement; principles of procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to meet residency requirement; judge erred in not providing fair opportunity to present case
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court Trial Division

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence in Canada during the four years preceding the application while studying abroad
Residency_Compliance: No, failed to accumulate 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal reviewed and dismissed by Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Appellant did not meet statutory residency requirement due to prolonged absence from Canada for studies

Application_Facts: Harry was absent from Canada for most of the required period, pursuing studies abroad and making only sporadic visits; he owned property in Canada but did not reside there sufficiently
Residency_Compliance: No – less than three years of physical presence in Canada within the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge to Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Records of travel and residence abroad, property ownership documents, application records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of physical residence in Canada during required period
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and overturning of citizenship denial
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Residency requires more than property ownership; physical presence in Canada for at least three of the past four years is mandatory and not satisfied

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Respondent misrepresented residency and whether the Citizenship Judge's decision was reasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reevaluation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's statements about absences were found to be false
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 29 of the Citizenship Act (false representation)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of number of days absent from Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancy between reported and actual absences (360 vs. 799 days)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Physical presence as primary test for residency
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Actual duration of absences and lack of credible ties to Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to failure to address misrepresentation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration of residency duration in application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in granting citizenship despite misrepresentation and insufficient proof of residency
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent provided inconsistent and false information on absences
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported residency data, official travel records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(1)(c) and Section 29 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet three-year physical residency requirement and false reporting
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Actual absences totaled 799 days, far exceeding claimed 360 days
Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrect reporting of days spent outside Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Statutory residency requirement based on physical presence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of documentation proving continuous residence and ties to Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of inaccurate residency information in citizenship application

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to threats from FARC but failed to seek state protection in Colombia.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision based on four issues raised by applicants.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of personal confrontation with FARC and supporting evidence.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found applicants not credible.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimants must prove lack of state protection and nexus to a Convention ground.
Decision_Rationale: The Board concluded adequate state protection existed in Colombia; court found this conclusion reasonable despite credibility assessment issues.

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F(b) of the Convention, Section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of drug offenses in the U.S., served jail time but left before completing probation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1F(b) of the Convention, Section 98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant committed drug offenses in the U.S., sentenced to jail and probation, departed before completing sentence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Committing a serious non-political crime abroad triggers exclusion regardless of partial sentence completion

Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Convicted in the U.S. of drug offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Controlled Drugs and Substances Act (Canada), Article 1F(b)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal sale of a controlled substance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether drug sale constitutes a serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: U.S. convictions for selling opium and possessing marijuana

Violation_Type: Credibility assessment without considering corroborating evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, particularly IRPA and the principles of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Bangladesh due to political activities; submitted testimony, psychological report indicating PTSD, and letters supporting political involvement and police issues
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of testimony by the claimant, as determined by the Refugee Division
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant evidence, including psychological and corroborating documents, before rejecting the claim
Evidence_Used: Personal testimony, psychological report on PTSD, letters supporting political involvement and police persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Panel did not address the psychological report or supporting letters in its decision
Credibility_Assessment: Panel dismissed claimant's testimony as fabricated without analyzing objective corroborating evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee Division rejected the applicants' claims based on credibility
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, found error in assessment
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Refugee Division’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative law; obligation to consider all relevant evidence under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The panel failed to properly assess credibility by disregarding independent corroborating evidence, violating procedural fairness
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Application_Facts: Applicant sustained a thumb injury in 1999; worked regularly until 2004; post-MQP diagnosis of delusional disorder
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of PAB's decision denying appeal rights
Evidence_Used: Medical records, work history, PAB assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing severe and prolonged disability by December 31, 2001
Decision_Outcome: PAB concluded no arguable case for disability benefits
Legal_Standard_Applied: Severe and prolonged disability as of minimum qualifying period (MQP); 'arguable case' test
Decision_Rationale: Thumb injury did not meet CPP disability criteria by MQP; post-MQP conditions irrelevant; applicant continued working

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of TRP application denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of denying TRP due to false statements or document issues
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubt on evidence of pardon and immigration history
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration records, lack of pardon documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unauthorized work, prior inadmissibility, lack of pardon proof
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: History of non-compliance and unresolved inadmissibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide evidence of pardon
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to CIC decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; court upheld CIC's assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Justified in the circumstances under IRPA s.24(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long immigration history with repeated TRPs

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of TRP refusal based on unauthorized employment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was unauthorized work a reasonable basis for denial?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible explanation for working post-permit expiry
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Work permit expiration records, employment history
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Engaged in unauthorized work after permit expired in December 2012
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that relevant evidence was ignored
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Justified in the circumstances under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Unauthorized work combined with other immigration violations
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not directly alleged, but linked to misrepresentation by omission

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal conviction under an Act of Parliament punishable by way of indictment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Prior conviction for impaired driving, claim of pardon not substantiated
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for Temporary Resident Permit (TRP)
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of TRPs but recent non-compliance issues
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness and bad faith by CIC
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal record, immigration file, pardon status inquiries
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of official documentation confirming pardon
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found no basis to question CIC's assessment
Crimes.Outcome: Inadmissibility maintained due to unproven criminal rehabilitation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn CIC's decision and grant TRP
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard except for extrinsic evidence (correctness)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: CIC acted within discretion; no procedural error found

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged past membership in AISSF, designated entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with proscribed group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Considered in context of overall admissibility
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Historical involvement despite long-standing TRP approvals
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Affiliation with organization linked to separatist violence
Crimes.Organization_Involved: AISSF (Anandpur Sahib Sikh Society / Babbar Khalsa affiliated?)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Past findings of involvement, though contested
Crimes.Leadership_Role: Not specified, but membership alone triggers inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: CIC relied on prior assessments; applicant failed to rebut
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of new evidence to overcome security-related inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, immigration history, prior determinations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims of changed circumstances not fully persuasive
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lengthy TRP history vs. failure to resolve core inadmissibility
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities in administrative proceedings
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of TRP denial based on security inadmissibility
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of temporary resident status and potential removal

Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Court Order
Application_Facts: Plaintiff failed to post security by the deadline but cited delayed freight payments and bank transfers as reasons.
Procedural_Issue: Defendant moved to dismiss the case; plaintiff sought an extension. Court analyzed compliance and extenuating factors.
Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff granted additional time to comply under specific conditions.
Outcome: Plaintiff's action will not be dismissed if full security is provided by July 11, 1997, along with amended claim, particulars, and payment of motion costs.
Relief_Sought: Plaintiff sought extension to provide security for costs.
Remedy_Sought: Defendant sought dismissal of the plaintiff's action.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Compliance with 'unless' order; excusable non-compliance due to extraneous circumstances.
Decision_Rationale: The court considered whether the plaintiff's failure was unintentional and due to extraneous circumstances such as financial delays. Found sufficient justification to allow cure of default under conditions.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Impaired driving over 80 mg of alcohol in 100 ml of blood
Application_Facts: Convicted of driving with a blood alcohol level of 147mg/100ml, nearly twice the legal limit
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed procedural fairness
Jurisdictional_Issue: Parole Board has exclusive jurisdiction under section 7(b)
Evidence_Used: Blood alcohol level, public safety risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Applicant no longer of good conduct due to impaired driving conviction

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of pardon revocation under Criminal Records Act
Governing_Law: Criminal Records Act, section 2.1 and paragraph 7(b)
Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for impaired driving considered as evidence of lack of good conduct
Legal_Rule: Board has discretion to revoke pardon if person is no longer of good conduct
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged lack of procedural fairness and unreasonable exercise of discretion
Key_Evidence_Considered: 2012 impaired driving conviction with high blood alcohol level
Legal_Provision: Section 2.1 and paragraph 7(b) of the Criminal Records Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Potential overstaying of temporary resident status
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a truck driver with family in India; applied for third work permit; assessed as having insufficient English proficiency (IELTS Band 4); considered young, single, and mobile raising concerns about intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Concerns about compliance with conditions of stay and intent to depart after permit expiration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Used: IELTS scores, job duties, personal circumstances (age, marital status, family ties in home country)
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of language proficiency and weak ties to home country
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's intent to leave Canada not sufficiently established
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of refusal
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded risk of overstaying due to personal factors and inadequate English for job requirements
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work permit refusal based on eligibility concerns
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa officer's refusal due to language proficiency and likelihood of departure
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review denied, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's language ability and intent to leave Canada questioned
Crimes.Evidence_Type: IELTS test results, job description, personal background
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPR s.200 – Work permit eligibility criteria
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient English proficiency (Band 4 vs required Band 5), risk of overstaying
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Language proficiency and applicant’s personal circumstances indicating high mobility and low incentive to return
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: General language demands of occupation, not just specific employer duties
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found by court; officer considered relevant factors
Crimes.Application_Factor: Third work permit application, prior experience as truck driver

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Shchegolevich was deemed inadmissible due to a conviction and denied H&C relief based on flawed reasoning.
Procedural_Issue: The Officer incorrectly applied the 'unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate' standard to the child's interests.
Evidence_Used: Assumption of temporary separation without evidence of easy re-entry
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting assumption of easy re-entry
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child
Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Decision_Rationale: Officer erred in assessing best interests of the child and impact of family separation

Dispute_Type: Denial of humanitarian and compassionate relief
Legal_Issue: Error in assessing best interests of the child and financial impact of removal
Legal_Rule: Best interests of a child must not require proof of irreparable harm
Grounds_for_Claim: Flawed legal reasoning and factual assumptions by Officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Impact of Mr. Shchegolevich's removal on family finances
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act - Humanitarian and Compassionate provisions

Violation_Type: Failure to meet residency requirement for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was absent from Canada for 776 days over a four-year period; maintained strong family ties in Canada, paid Canadian taxes, and intended to retire in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Partially non-compliant with physical presence but demonstrated centralization of mode of existence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Minister challenged the citizenship judge's assessment of residency compliance
Evidence_Used: Family ties in Canada
Tax payment records
Intent to return and retire in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found the Respondent's evidence credible and sufficient
Relief_Sought: Minister sought to overturn approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of citizenship grant based on alleged insufficient residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence test
Decision_Rationale: Despite absences, the Respondent maintained significant connections to Canada, satisfying the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court reviewing citizenship judge's decision

Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate (H&C) Grounds Application Rejection
Application_Facts: Ms. Jung claimed hardship due to potential abuse in Korea; Officer found stronger ties to Korea, no personalized risk, and sufficient economic stability in Canada
Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Evidence_Used: Assessment of ties to Korea, risk of abuse, economic stability in Canada
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Remedy_Sought: Certification of a question or overturning of decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was reasonable and within legislative discretion; no error in law or fact identified

Application_Facts: The applicants' counsel was absent due to illness, and they were informed the hearing would proceed regardless. They did not provide evidence of an adjournment request or demonstrate how the absence of counsel affected their ability to present their case.
Procedural_Issue: Proceeding with the hearing in the absence of counsel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: The applicants did not provide evidence of an adjournment request or demonstrate how the absence of counsel affected their ability to present their case.
Decision_Outcome: The applicants' refugee claim was denied.
Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed the application, upholding the Board's decision.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review arguing a breach of natural justice due to the absence of legal representation.
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that the Board breached natural justice or procedural fairness.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Proceeding without counsel is not inherently a breach of natural justice; the key is whether the absence deprived the individual of a fair hearing.
Decision_Rationale: No breach of natural justice or procedural fairness was found as the applicants failed to show that the absence of counsel prejudiced their ability to present their case.

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of physical presence within four years prior to application
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for Canadian citizenship; claimed residency based on CBSA data and passport records; discrepancies in banking statements; limitations in CBSA reports not addressed
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient evidence to confirm 1095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Second citizenship judge failed to adequately analyze evidence; insufficient reasoning in decision
Evidence_Used: CBSA data
passport records
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Discrepancies in banking statements not addressed
Limitations of CBSA reports not considered
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by a different judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence requirement under Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The second judge's approval was based on incomplete analysis of residency evidence, rendering the decision unreasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant appeared without counsel twice, confirmed readiness to proceed, no adjournment requested, Board used interpreters and explanations to ensure understanding
Procedural_Issue: Lack of counsel, request for adjournment not made, fairness of hearing
Outcome: No breach of natural justice or procedural fairness found
Legal_Standard_Applied: Right to a fair hearing, meaningful participation
Decision_Rationale: Applicant confirmed readiness to proceed, right to counsel is not absolute, Board ensured understanding through interpreters and explanations

Legal_Provision_Violated: section 41(1)(c) and (e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed sex discrimination; position eliminated in 2002; complaint filed in 2003; mediation outcomes did not prove discrimination
Procedural_Issue: Complaint filed over one year after alleged act, exceeding statutory time limit
Jurisdictional_Issue: Commission's authority to decline complaints based on timeliness and lack of discriminatory evidence
Evidence_Used: Mediation outcomes
Decision_Outcome: Commission declined to deal with the complaint
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; costs awarded to respondent
Legal_Standard_Applied: Complaints may be declined under section 41(1)(c) and (e) if not discriminatory or filed beyond one-year limit
Decision_Rationale: No error by the Commission in declining the complaint due to lack of evidence and late filing

Application_Facts: The Electoral Code was validly adopted in 2005, but its suspension in 2006 lacked proper procedure and consensus. The process involved misleading information and bypassed required protocols.
Misrepresentation_Element: Misleading information was provided during the suspension process.
Procedural_Issue: Suspension of the Electoral Code bypassed required protocols and did not follow established procedures.
Decision_Outcome: 2006 elections were annulled; illegally elected members removed via writ of quo warranto.
Outcome: New elections ordered under the original Electoral Code.
Relief_Sought: Judicial review to challenge the 2006 election results.
Remedy_Sought: Annulment of elections, removal of illegal members, and new elections.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Validity of electoral code based on adoption process and compliance with customs.
Decision_Rationale: The suspension of the Electoral Code was invalid due to lack of proper procedure and consensus, rendering the 2006 elections illegal.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of their time in Canada due to business-related absences; physical presence fell short of required 1,095 days within four years
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 3-year physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply the Koo test
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Business success and international travel records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of meaningful ties to Canada under Koo criteria
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for assessing residency in absence of full physical presence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge improperly substituted business justifications for actual physical attachment to Canada; ignored key Koo factors

Crimes.Violation_Type: False or misleading representation regarding residency
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of time in Canada; significant absences for business; only two of six Koo factors favored residency claim
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Applications approved despite clear failure to meet residency obligations, implying inaccurate assessment of facts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper application of Koo test by Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel history, business activities abroad, limited connections to Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation demonstrating strong residential ties to Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for qualitative assessment of residency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge unreasonably prioritized business needs over statutory residency requirements and established Koo criteria

Application_Facts: Mr. Le Minh Duc Tran applied for a study permit; the Visa Officer assessed his credibility, English proficiency, and financial viability.
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness due to insufficient notice of phone interview and no opportunity to respond to concerns
Evidence_Used: Assessment of applicant's English language skills, financial situation, and stated study intentions
Credibility_Assessment: Visa Officer questioned Mr. Tran's credibility as a bona fide student based on weak English skills and financial viability
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the visa refusal and issuance of a study permit
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness (relaxed standard), assessment of bona fide student status
Decision_Rationale: The court found no breach of procedural fairness due to relaxed standards in visa cases and determined the officer’s credibility assessment was not patently unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Federal Court (for judicial review)

Legal_Issue: Was the decision to revoke Mr. Clue's Transportation Security Clearance (TSC) procedurally fair and supported by evidence?
Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Clue was uncooperative during investigations
Evidence_Type: Alleged placement of a loaded handgun on an aircraft
Legal_Provision: Section related to TSC under Aeronautics Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged involvement in placing a loaded handgun on an aircraft

Violation_Type: Potential unlawful interference with civil aviation
Application_Facts: Alleged involvement in loading a handgun onto an aircraft
Uncooperative behavior
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in revocation process
Evidence_Used: Alleged handgun incident
Behavior during investigation
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: Reasonable belief of potential security threat

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and evidentiary support for TSC revocation

Violation_Type: Claiming refugee status without meeting eligibility criteria
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), subsection 97(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant born in Russia, resided in Latvia, claimed statelessness and fear of persecution due to discrimination in Latvia
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Applicant resides outside country of nationality (Russia) but maintains effective link to Russia
Misrepresentation_Element: Claimed statelessness despite ability to readily acquire Russian citizenship
Procedural_Issue: Panel reviewed case; Federal Court assessed correctness of citizenship determination
Evidence_Used: Documentation showing applicant can obtain Russian citizenship by submitting application and passport for stamping
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating genuine inability to access Russian citizenship
Credibility_Assessment: Claim of statelessness found not credible due to accessible citizenship process in Russia
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Applicant is not stateless as she can easily acquire Russian citizenship; therefore, does not meet definition of Convention refugee
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) Panel, Federal Court

Legal_Provision: Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Section 18.2 of the Federal Court Act
Assessment_Standard: Tri-partite test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Outcome: Conditional stay until judicial review concludes

Legal_Issue: Whether the marriage was genuine or entered into primarily for immigration purposes
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of financial intermingling, unreliable documentary evidence
Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision was quashed due to breach of procedural fairness
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate genuineness of marriage
Credibility_Factor: Credibility of couple's testimony and supporting documentation
Legal_Rule: A marriage not considered genuine if entered into primarily for immigration purposes
Grounds_for_Claim: Breach of procedural fairness, failure to consider relevant evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Testimony of the couple, financial records, documentary evidence of relationship
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: IAD found marriage not genuine based on inconsistencies and lack of integration
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of IAD decision and re-determination
Outcome: Application allowed, matter returned for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Decision_Outcome: May 5, 1992 decision quashed, effects stayed pending new tribunal
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to demonstrate procedural unfairness
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions must adhere to procedural fairness standards, including unbiased tribunal, proper notice, and right to representation
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on context
Grounds_for_Claim: Bias, lack of proper notice, denial of right to representation
Outcome_on_Merits: Procedural unfairness found; decision set aside
Key_Evidence_Considered: Tribunal proceedings, notice documentation, participation records
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision, redetermination by new tribunal
Outcome: Decision quashed, stay of effect, new tribunal ordered
Authority: Cowessess Indian Band #73 Appeal Tribunal, judicial review court

Legal_Issue: Whether failure to use the trademark 'Fascination' for three years constitutes special circumstances excusing non-use under s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Appellant provided no evidence of when use would resume or specific obstacles preventing use; recession deemed a common situation, not special circumstances
Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to prove special circumstances justifying non-use
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible evidence from appellant regarding future use or external obstacles
Legal_Rule: Under s. 45(3), a trademark may be expunged if not in use and absence of use is not due to special circumstances beyond the owner's control
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and application of s. 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-use of trademark for over three years without justification by special circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: Appellant failed to meet burden; claim rejected
Key_Evidence_Considered: Economic conditions cited as reason for non-use; lack of evidence on timing of resumption or specific impediments
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, administrative and appellate review procedures
Defendant_Response: Economic downturn (recession) as reason for non-use
Evidence_Type: Oral/affidavit evidence on economic conditions, lack of documentary evidence on future plans
Outcome: Trademark 'Fascination' expunged; costs awarded to respondent

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and identity of the applicant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found lacking credibility due to inconsistencies and implausibilities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return to North Korea
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 72(1) of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Speculative findings and insufficient consideration of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to prove identity and risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Corroborative evidence dismissed without sufficient basis
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation of identity and nationality documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Establishment of credible identity as a North Korean citizen
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in narrative and implausibilities in testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, referred back for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove identity and nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Doubts about dialect expertise and authenticity of supporting letters
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove identity and nationality for refugee status
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Credible fear of persecution in North Korea
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed to be North Korean defector seeking protection
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of judicial review and referral for re-hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving credibility and entry method
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Speculative rejection of key evidence without proper justification
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Corroborative evidence submitted but inadequately assessed
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged smuggling involvement through irregular border crossing
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No explicit criminal record, but credibility concerns raised
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential misrepresentation and lack of verified identity
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of persecution if returned to North Korea
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Board Member at Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Outcome: Reconsideration ordered by different Board member
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to properly assess evidence and reliance on speculation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Credibility undermining through false statements or omissions
Crimes.Governing_Law: Statutory interpretation and procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed North Korean origin but faced credibility challenges
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entered Canada and made a refugee claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper discounting of affidavits and speculative assumptions
Evidence_Used: Helen Park's affidavit
Jinsa Park's letter
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentary proof of nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistent and implausible by Board
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter referred for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of negative refugee determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a different decision maker

Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Credibility_Assessment: Doubted identity and conversion due to inconsistent testimony and document conditions
Legal_Provision: Assessment of credibility based on documentation or reasonable explanations for absence
Basis_of_Claim: Conversion to Christianity, fear of persecution
Assessment_Standard: Reasonable possibility of persecution supported by credible evidence
Evidence_Ignored: No proof that documents were fake

Legal_Issue: Did the Board commit a reviewable error in basing its decision on findings of fact made in a perverse or capricious manner?
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Credibility_Assessment: The Board doubted Akram's subjective and objective fear of persecution due to inconsistencies in his claims and implausibility of events
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in claims, implausibility of events
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant argued key evidence was ignored, but court found it was reasonably assessed
Legal_Standard: Patent unreasonableness requires deference to credibility findings unless based on erroneous facts or ignored evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld; no reviewable error found

Crime_Name: Use of false documents for international travel
Legal_Issue: Did the Board commit a reviewable error in its credibility findings?
Credibility_Assessment: The Board doubted Akram's claims due to inconsistencies such as lack of action on previous refugee claims and implausible threats
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution fears and use of false documents for travel
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in claims, lack of follow-up on prior claims, implausible threats
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Assessment_Standard: Credibility findings must not be patently unreasonable or based on erroneous facts
Evidence_Ignored: No evidence that the Board ignored key testimony or documentation
Decision_Outcome: Court dismissed judicial review; Board's decision upheld
Document_Fraud: Use of false documents for international travel

Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff's statement of claim discloses a reasonable cause of action in negligence
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's claim found vague, lacking specific facts and particulars
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish all elements of negligence
Legal_Rule: To establish negligence: (1) damage, (2) causation, (3) breach of standard of care, (4) duty of care, (5) proximate cause, (6) absence of contributory negligence
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable cause of action test; generous interpretation applied
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged negligence by defendant causing damage
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to failure to plead essential elements
Key_Evidence_Considered: Statement of claim filed by plaintiff
Defendant_Response: Motion to strike out for failure to disclose cause of action
Outcome: Claim struck out without leave to amend; dismissed as frivolous and vexatious
Legal_Provision: Rules of Court regarding pleading standards

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on foreign criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in assessing the U.S. offence and identifying an equivalent Canadian offence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence showed intentional misrepresentation by the applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of false claim of U.S. citizenship
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of U.S. citizenship to obtain a loan
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged error in equivalence assessment of foreign offence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Act outside Canada equivalent to Canadian offence punishable by 10+ years
Crimes.Application_Factor: Foreign national committing act abroad equivalent to serious Canadian crime
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False claim of citizenship in loan application

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on foreign criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Tribunal erred in assessing the U.S. offence and identifying its Canadian equivalent
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Tribunal's inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence of false citizenship claim to obtain loan
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show error in Tribunal's decision
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant fled before sentencing, indicating consciousness of guilt
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Foreign act equivalent to Canadian offence punishable by 10+ years imprisonment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to equivalence of U.S. fraud offence with Canadian s.380
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: False representation of citizenship to secure financial benefit
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant applied for judicial review contesting inadmissibility

Crime_Name: Importing cocaine contrary to Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation due to lack of appeal rights
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crime_Name: Acknowledging an instrument in a false name under Criminal Code
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Criminal Code
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Defendant_Response: Challenged dismissal of appeal due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's determination that adequate state protection exists in Colombia is reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board considered both favorable and conflicting evidence regarding state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants failed to demonstrate inability or unwillingness to avail themselves of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' actions were found inconsistent with genuine fear; lack of reporting to authorities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – reasonableness standard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution by FARC and insufficient state protection in Colombia
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to adequate state protection despite imperfections
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Government efforts to combat guerrilla groups, availability of protection in Bogota, applicants’ failure to report threats
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board emphasized existence of state mechanisms and applicant credibility issues
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court upheld the Board's decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted threats from organized armed group
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of state protection programs in urban areas like Bogota
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Ongoing human rights violations by FARC but declining state control
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – involving death threats and forced recruitment
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: General risk in rural areas, lower in urban centers with state presence
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on refusal to comply with demands
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient to establish lack of state protection due to unreported incidents
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Questioned due to inconsistencies and failure to seek asylum elsewhere
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants’ fear deemed not subjectively genuine
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Convention refugee criteria

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on intimidation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board’s finding on subjective fear and state protection
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board assessed credibility based on lack of police reporting and alternative asylum options
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants did not meet burden to show inability to access state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report threats and bypassing U.S. asylum opportunity undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA requires both subjective and objective components
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC after refusing demands
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to sufficient state protection and credibility concerns
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Lack of engagement with Colombian authorities, possibility of internal relocation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International and domestic refugee law standards
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Board cited functional state institutions and applicant inconsistencies
Crimes.Outcome: Board’s decision upheld by Federal Court
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Risk_Factor: Non-disclosure affecting eligibility for family class sponsorship
Crimes.Credibility: Not directly challenged; omission attributed to refugee constraints

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose common law partner in permanent residence application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration application integrity and disclosure obligations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Omission of common-law partner in permanent residence application affecting sponsorship eligibility
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Outcome: IAD allowed appeal and remitted case to visa officer; Federal Court dismissed judicial review

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IAD's findings and interpretation of law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – court found IAD considered relevant evidence

Dispute_Type: Trademark infringement liability of corporate officer
Legal_Issue: Whether there is a genuine issue for trial regarding Mr. Kichuk's personal liability for trademark infringement
Governing_Law: Principles of personal liability for directors and officers in trademark infringement
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Kichuk conducted a trademark search that did not reveal the 'ISO-FLEX' mark; he had no prior knowledge of the plaintiffs or their products; post-adoption events were considered but found insufficient to establish liability
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs failed to show genuine issue of material fact regarding personal liability
Credibility_Factor: Defendant's lack of knowledge and good faith adoption of the mark
Legal_Rule: Directors and officers are personally liable if their conduct is tortious or shows deliberate, willful indifference to the risk of infringement
Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard – whether a genuine issue for trial exists
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged personal involvement in trademark infringement through corporate actions
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed on merits due to lack of evidence supporting personal liability
Key_Evidence_Considered: Trademark search results, defendant’s knowledge (or lack thereof), timing of mark adoption, absence of willful infringement
Legal_Framework: U.S. trademark law principles on vicarious and direct liability for corporate officers
Defendant_Response: Lack of knowledge, good faith selection of mark, no deliberate or willful conduct
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (trademark search), sworn statements, procedural record
Remedy_Requested: Dismissal of claims against Mr. Kichuk and Mr. Glover
Outcome: Summary judgment granted, claims dismissed with costs
Legal_Provision: Federal trademark law (implied under Lanham Act principles)
Authority: Court decision on motion for summary judgment

Legal_Issue: Interpretation and application of the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act
Evidence_Assessment: Comprehensive Study Review (CSR), reliance on provincial initiatives (e.g., RSDS)
Decision_Outcome: MOE's decision found wrong in law; MFO's decisions deemed unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On public interest groups to demonstrate legal error and unreasonableness
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on provincial processes beyond federal control undermined credibility of mitigation claims
Legal_Rule: The Minister must assess significant adverse environmental effects, including cumulative impacts, considering effective mitigation measures within federal authority
Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of statutory duties, reliance on non-enforceable provincial measures, flawed authorization process
Outcome_on_Merits: Applications allowed; declarations issued against MOE and MFO decisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: CSR findings, provincial RSDS framework, mitigation commitments
Legal_Framework: Federal environmental assessment regime under CEAA
Defendant_Response: Approval based on assumption that provincial mitigation measures were sufficient and enforceable
Evidence_Type: Administrative records, CSR documentation, statutory provisions
Remedy_Requested: Declaration of unlawful decision-making, quashing of approvals
Outcome: Declarations issued; no quashing due to project completion
